bill_title: to specify certain circumstances that create a rebuttable presumption that awarding custody or granting visitation rights is not in the best interests of a child.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to specify certain circumstances that create a rebuttable presumption that awarding custody or granting visitation rights is not in the best interests of a child. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. In awarding custody involving a minor, the court shall consider evidence of domestic abuse as defined in § 25-10-1(1). If the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that domestic abuse has occurred, this evidence creates a rebuttable presumption that awarding custody to the abusive parent is not in the best interests of the minor. Section 2. In awarding custody or granting rights of visitation involving a minor, the court shall consider a conviction of a parent for the death of the other parent. A conviction for the death of the other parent creates a rebuttable presumption that awarding custody or granting visitation to the convicted parent is not in the best interests of the minor. 750 copies of this document were printed by the South Dakota Legislative Research Council at a cost of $.015 per page. . Insertions into existing statutes are indicated by underscores. Deletions from existing statutes are indicated by overstrikes.

FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to specify certain circumstances that create a rebuttable presumption that awarding custody or granting visitation rights is not in the best interests of a child. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. In awarding custody involving a minor, the court shall consider a conviction of domestic abuse as defined in § 25-10-1(1) or a conviction of assault against a person as defined in § 25-10-1(2). The conviction creates a rebuttable presumption that awarding custody to the abusive parent is not in the best interests of the minor. Section 2. In awarding custody or granting rights of visitation involving a minor, the court shall consider a conviction, excluding vehicular homicide, of a parent for the death of the other parent. A conviction for the death of the other parent creates a rebuttable presumption that awarding custody or granting visitation to the convicted parent is not in the best interests of the minor. BILL HISTORY 1/29/97 First read in Senate and referred to Judiciary. S.J. 219 2/10/97 Scheduled for Committee hearing on this date. 2/12/97 Scheduled for Committee hearing on this date. 2/12/97 Judiciary Do Pass Amended, AYES 7, NAYS 0. 2/13/97 Motion to Amend. S.J. 435 2/13/97 Senate Do Pass Amended, AYES 33, NAYS 1. S.J. 435

FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to specify certain circumstances that create a rebuttable presumption that awarding custody or granting visitation rights is not in the best interests of a child. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. In awarding custody involving a minor, the court shall consider a conviction of domestic abuse as defined in § 25-10-1(1) or a conviction of assault against a person as defined in § 25-10-1(2), except against any person related by consanguinity, but not living in the same household. The conviction creates a rebuttable presumption that awarding custody to the abusive parent is not in the best interests of the minor. Section 2. In awarding custody or granting rights of visitation involving a minor, the court shall consider a conviction, excluding vehicular homicide, of a parent for the death of the other parent. A conviction for the death of the other parent creates a rebuttable presumption that awarding custody or granting visitation to the convicted parent is not in the best interests of the minor. BILL HISTORY 1/29/97 First read in Senate and referred to Judiciary. S.J. 219 2/10/97 Scheduled for Committee hearing on this date. 2/12/97 Scheduled for Committee hearing on this date. 2/12/97 Judiciary Do Pass Amended, Passed, AYES 7, NAYS 0. 2/13/97 Motion to Amend, Passed. S.J. 435 2/13/97 Senate Do Pass Amended, Passed, AYES 33, NAYS 1. S.J. 435 2/14/97 First read in House and referred to Judiciary. H.J. 500 2/28/97 Scheduled for Committee hearing on this date. 2/28/97 Judiciary Do Pass Amended, Passed, AYES 8, NAYS 4. H.J. 771
